abstract: When my daughter was born, it was the begining of the end of my marriage.
snippet: When my daughter was born, it was the begining of the end of my marriage.
lead_paragraph: “IT’S a girl.”

headline.main: Have That Baby, Dear. I’ll Just Watch.
headline.print_headline: Have That Baby, Dear. I’ll Just Watch.

abstract: The profligate 20-something and the trip to India that turned out not to be a lie.
snippet: The profligate 20-something and the trip to India that turned out not to be a lie.
lead_paragraph: The winter of 1991 found me stunned and shivering in the aftermath of an imploded love affair. Being 26, I flung myself actorishly on London and without any intimations of my own ludicrousness spent two years showing God what I thought of him by letting myself go. I drank and took drugs sufficient to give me bleeding gums and a Parkinsonian head wobble, conditions that compromised but did not prevent my other main hobby — having sex as often as possible. A lot of girls didn’t mind. A lot of them had troubles of their own. It was a cheering surprise, the sort of dismal shape you could be in and still get into some maenadic self-harmer’s pants. Granted, these encounters never developed — no morning-after breakfast or fun in the shower — but encased as I was in the armor of nihilism, I wouldn’t have stuck around for any of that rubbish anyway.

headline.main: Young Man Behaving Badly
headline.print_headline: Young Man Behaving Badly

abstract: While in her 60s, Lynette Byers of Harlem accepted a challenge few would have: adopting three siblings.
snippet: While in her 60s, Lynette Byers of Harlem accepted a challenge few would have: adopting three siblings.
lead_paragraph: Lynette Byers was in her early 60s when she became a mother for the second time. She had been married, raised a son to adulthood, worked for years as a private pediatric nurse and lived in her Harlem apartment for decades when a scrawny 9-month-old named Curtis came into her life. He was sickly, and his mother could not care for him. He was not expected to live.

snippet: The house where my wife had had a great time decorating — that house belonged to a life that was no longer mine.
lead_paragraph: A MISCONCEPTION among some people is that I wrote the novel “Kramer vs. Kramer” based on my own divorce and custody battle. “How is she doing with his son?” a woman once asked a friend of ours about my wife. Our friend answered, “They have two sons and they’re both hers.”

headline.print_headline: Moving Through Grief, Chair by Chair

abstract: Photos of Bruce Godschalk in process of resuming his life after spending decade and a half behind bars for rape he did not commit; he was released from Pennsylvania jail in February after being cleared by DNA test
snippet: Photos of Bruce Godschalk in process of resuming his life after spending decade and a half behind bars for rape he did not commit; he was released from Pennsylvania jail in February after being cleared by DNA test
lead_paragraph: In February, a decade and a half after he was arrested when he was a 26-year-old landscaper, Bruce Godschalk walked out of a Pennsylvania jail, exonerated by DNA tests ordered by a federal judge last fall. ''I was a young man when I went into jail, and when I came out I was middle-aged,'' Godschalk says. ''That's the hard part.'' Both his parents and his only sibling, a sister, died while he was incarcerated, so Godschalk spent the night of his release at a lawyer's house before starting over.

abstract: Can a relationship built on lies ultimately be good for you?
snippet: Can a relationship built on lies ultimately be good for you?
lead_paragraph: James was all over my dog, Cindy, photographing her and posting her to his Facebook. He would roughhouse and then curl around her, pinning Cindy down and forcing her to look him in the eyes: a deep, locked gaze that said they were connected, that said he belonged in this apartment with this dog.

abstract: This summer in Lebanon, even a childhood retreat offered no relief.
snippet: This summer in Lebanon, even a childhood retreat offered no relief.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, after my father died, I decided to renovate our family home in Noumairieh, the small village in southern Lebanon where I grew up. My friends told me I was crazy. They said I would end up spending a lot of money on a house that I’d never visit. As a Beiruti, I didn’t belong there anymore. And they were right in a way.

abstract: Through my scheming search, I’d actually found love, and instead of me getting his flight benefits, he got mine.
snippet: Through my scheming search, I’d actually found love, and instead of me getting his flight benefits, he got mine.
lead_paragraph: I GOT married a few months ago, but my husband  a proud Air Force pilot from a small town in Georgia  doesn’t know how we met. Rather, he doesn’t know the path that led me to him. By the time he was perched on one knee and presenting an engagement ring, I feared it was too late to tell the love of my life that we had been brought together not by fate but as a result of my nationwide crusade to find a pilot.

headline.main: How I Earned My Wings Back
headline.print_headline: How I Earned My Wings Back

abstract: A homemade campaign to beat drug dealers.
snippet: A homemade campaign to beat drug dealers.
lead_paragraph: It was 1985. I was 12 and standing next to my mother in a police station in Greenwich Village. She was a pretty red-haired gal in her late 30s, but the three police officers she was talking to weren’t looking at her. They were looking at the bag of crack vials she had in her hands, confused about what they were. I wasn’t confused. We had a lot of crack vials in our apartment at that point. Hundreds of them. My brothers and I played with them in Washington Square Park. We carried them around in our pockets the way other kids carried marbles.

headline.main: How My Mom Discovered Crack

What do you do when you raise a child to care deeply about the world and that child turns into a young woman who cares so deeply that she moves from verdant Washington to desiccated Gaza to become a human shield?

abstract: Lance Cpt Derrick Jensen Lives column, as told to Peter Mo
snippet: Lance Cpt Derrick Jensen Lives column, as told to Peter Mo
lead_paragraph: First off I want people to understand that there is more than just combat. We're not seeing fighting at all times. Sometimes accidents happen. The other night, a good friend of mine, Lance Cpl. William White, and I were driving along in a Humvee. We were setting up communication because we were both com guys. It was night. I was driving. I had my night-vision goggles on. You know N.V.G.'s aren't the best; they're good, but your perception is not the greatest with them. When I came up on the hole, I didn't see it. The Humvee pretty much slipped into a canal and tipped upside down into the water. The cab we were in, me and him, completely flooded. Of course, I panicked. We were underwater. It definitely was a scary situation. You've got to stop and think, but you don't really have time to stop and think. You've got to be quick about it and decide, What do I need to do here, where do I need to go?

abstract: Paul Scott article describes experience of being held up by robber who stuttered, while working as night cashier in Minneapolis convenience store (M)
snippet: Paul Scott article describes experience of being held up by robber who stuttered, while working as night cashier in Minneapolis convenience store (M)
lead_paragraph: It's the last year of high school, and I'm not sure why I have this job. It is where I wait for my next check, which comes out to just enough for a new pair of sneakers a level above what Mom would have financed. Nights, I sit waiting for something to happen. It's Minneapolis, after all. I am focused, eyeballing the Rice-a-Roni's, the cans of 10W-40 and cartons of Merit Lights, asking if there will be anything else today.

lead_paragraph: Emie Payen has an ease to her cadence and a subdued sense of humor that belies the struggles, losses and health crises she has endured most of her life. It is a disposition forged by gratitude — Ms. Payen, 55, never expected to live past her mid-30s.

I had been going to the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn., for six months and had no idea there was a Trader Joe’s nearby.

headline.print_headline: A Life to Live, This Side of the Bars

abstract: Jean Thompson memoir of her longterm friendship with Ben, writer who drank too much, who would call her in middle of night after drinking to read what he had been writing, and who finally died in car wreck after night out drinking (M)
snippet: Jean Thompson memoir of her longterm friendship with Ben, writer who drank too much, who would call her in middle of night after drinking to read what he had been writing, and who finally died in car wreck after night out drinking (M)
lead_paragraph: Back then, my phone would ring at 1 or 2 o'clock in the morning, and Ben's voice would be in my ear. No greeting or preamble, just the crackle of his notebook's pages and the words unspooling. That was what he liked to do, ambush me with a story, jump out of the darkness and mug me with it. ''It's Ben,'' I'd whisper to my boyfriend, who'd groan himself back to sleep. I'd listen for however long he read, sometimes drifting off, or trying gamely to follow along and make appreciative noises.

abstract: For a mother and her young children, conflict in the Middle East means staying put.
snippet: For a mother and her young children, conflict in the Middle East means staying put.
lead_paragraph: Since the start of the new fighting between Hezbollah and Israel, a helicopter has been circling my neighborhood in Tel Aviv — about 70 miles south of where Hezbollah missiles began falling on July 12. When I first noticed the helicopter, I associated it with the sound of the old ride-on lawn mower my great-grandfather used to cut his grass in Houston. For a moment, I went there, to the quiet suburb where I grew up, and smelled the freshly cut grass, and my grandmother’s challah baking in the oven. And I recalled the two things my grandmother taught me best: to be Jewish, and to be afraid. She should be proud. I am excelling in both.

headline.main: For the Boy Who Makes Waves
headline.print_headline: For the Boy Who Makes Waves

abstract: Hugo Perez article on encountering Spalding Gray on Staten Island ferry on the evening he apparently jumped off ferry and died (M)
snippet: Hugo Perez article on encountering Spalding Gray on Staten Island ferry on the evening he apparently jumped off ferry and died (M)
lead_paragraph: If you read enough detective fiction, you are repeatedly told that people often return to the scene of the crime. I'm not a criminal, but guilt did compel me to return to the Staten Island ferry. I felt I should have sensed that something was off on the night I met Spalding Gray, the night he disappeared. When I heard three days later that he was missing, I called the police; I did the things one should do, but it didn't seem like enough. I knew that nothing would come of riding the ferry again, but in some small, deluded way, I thought there was a chance I would find him still riding the ferry back and forth, riding and waiting for someone to recognize him and take him home. In the little fantasy running through my head, I would find him standing at the back of the ferry, and this time I would say, ''Spalding, let me take you home.''

headline.main: Desperately Still Seeking Spalding
headline.print_headline: LIVES; Desperately Still Seeking Spalding

snippet: An elderly widow in Manhattan was stabbed and forced to leave her apartment after a fire. Then her son died. She pays a maintenance fee to keep her ruined apartment in her name while it is repaired.
lead_paragraph: Isabella Rivera, 86, had expected to live out a quiet, peaceful life in her golden years. But she did not count on the naked attacker armed with a knife. She did not count on losing a second son to illness. And she did not count on being forced out of her home because of a fire.

lead_paragraph: MY life’s greatest sorrow stems from my inability to feel close to other women. At 41, I’ve cautiously cultivated a few cherished female friendships. But generally I feel a kind of skittish distrust and discomfort when dealing with most women, particularly women in packs.

abstract: Family members may be closer than they appear from half a world away.
snippet: Family members may be closer than they appear from half a world away.
lead_paragraph: Recently, my Indian grandmother visited the United States for a prolonged stay. She has made this journey several times, but she is 79 now, and my mother said that this would be her last trip. Since her last visit I had become a mother, and my grandmother made a point of delaying her return to India so that she could attend Maya’s first birthday celebration at my home in Boston.

He put himself through two years of business courses at the Fashion Institute of Technology by working as an office assistant.

abstract: Finding the child I put up for adoption led to a bonus: my grandchild.
snippet: Finding the child I put up for adoption led to a bonus: my grandchild.
lead_paragraph: BECAUSE of a twist of fate, I became a grandmother nearly concurrently with becoming a mother, not long after I was reunited with the daughter I had given up for adoption decades before. By the time I found her — I was 42 and she 25 — my daughter, who would soon have a child herself, had been with several mothers, but none who had stayed. And I had never had another child. In this way we needed each other; our wounds were clean and deep.

snippet: Jackie Marhalik writes Lives column on serving on jury that convicted John Allen Muhammad of murder in Washington-area sniper case and sentenced him to death (M)
lead_paragraph: In early September, I got a court summons. I knew there had been some murders in Virginia, Maryland and D.C. last year, but my nephew was about to get married at my house, so I was very busy making decorations and planting flowers. I didn't even realize that John Allen Muhammad was being tried in Virginia Beach, where I've lived for 15 years. I'm 51. When I was divorced, I opened a travel agency and then sold that, and now I'm in real estate.

headline.main: NYT: Modern Love for 11/18/2006

abstract: With older parents come new holiday traditions.
snippet: With older parents come new holiday traditions.
lead_paragraph: As we pull up after a five-hour drive from Maine for Christmas at my parents’ house in Connecticut, my husband and I notice that their car is not in the driveway. That’s unusual for my mom and dad, who are both in their 80s. They stopped coming North a few years ago after episodes involving forgotten medications and midnight visits to the emergency room. I’ve baked pies and cookies according to recipes that I got from my mom, which she got from her mom, back so far in time that amounts are in pounds and pecks. My oldest, Kelly, has flown East to come with us. Her teenage sister, Hannah, is looking forward to seeing her grandparents. Holiday meals used to include about 20 relatives; every table in the house was brought into the dining room. Tonight it will be my parents, my brother and my family.

headline.print_headline: My So-Called (Instagram) Life

abstract: Meeting a childhood friend during missile strikes in Israel, again.
snippet: Meeting a childhood friend during missile strikes in Israel, again.
lead_paragraph: When the fighting in Gaza began last month, I found myself with a lot of spare time. The university in Beersheeba where I teach was within the range of missiles fired by Hamas, and they had to close it. But after a couple of weeks, it reopened, and the next day I found myself taking an hour-and-a-half train ride from Tel Aviv, where I live, to Beersheeba again. Half the students weren’t there — mainly the ones from the center of the country — but the other half, those living in Beersheeba itself, showed up. The bombs were dropping on them in any case, and conventional wisdom among the students was that the university’s classrooms were better protected than their dorms and housing projects.

headline.main: Matchstick War
headline.print_headline: Matchstick War

abstract: A troubled teen from a Bronx housing project finds solace during his weekend trips to a camp in the Hudson River Valley.
snippet: A troubled teen from a Bronx housing project finds solace during his weekend trips to a camp in the Hudson River Valley.
lead_paragraph: The two school-age tenants of a chilly and cramped unit in a Bronx public housing complex are not allowed outside alone. That is their mother’s policy, and not without reason: the mobile police station is no longer positioned nearby. Had it still been there, some in the complex say, perhaps a neighbor might not have been shot recently, in midmorning.

headline.main: Camp Offers a Young Boy Peace, Inside and Out
headline.print_headline: The Neediest Cases: Camp Offers a Young Boy Peace, Inside and Out

abstract: With parenthood dampening her romantic options, a woman changes her strategy.
snippet: With parenthood dampening her romantic options, a woman changes her strategy.
lead_paragraph: The nicest thing I own is the first thing you see when you walk into my house: a red handmade rug bought in Tehran, haggled over in Farsi and delivered, in person, to the Brooklyn apartment of the man who would become my husband.

headline.main: A Single Mom Escapes the Friend Zone, One Non-Date at a Time
headline.print_headline: Escaping the Friend Zone

abstract: In Kenya, the everyday becomes day to day.
snippet: In Kenya, the everyday becomes day to day.
lead_paragraph: We should have seen it coming. The violence between the Luo and the Kikuyu tribes that started after the December elections was spreading again down Kenya’s Rift Valley. By Sunday evening, there was news that 19 people, including women and children, all Luos, had been burned in a house in Naivasha. But by Monday morning in Kisumu, the Luo-dominated city in western Kenya, everybody went about business normally.

snippet: Even while facing many medical problems, James Leak has taken literacy classes, battled to preserve his mobility and kept his apartment in Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: James Leak turned 70 last week, but he only recently started learning to read and write.

headline.main: At 70, Still Fighting to Live Independently
headline.print_headline: At 70, Still Fighting to Live Independently

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Sarita James Modern Love article on her parents' attempts to find her 'suitable boy' to marry who is both Indian and Catholic; drawing (M)
snippet: Sarita James Modern Love article on her parents' attempts to find her 'suitable boy' to marry who is both Indian and Catholic; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: MY Suitable Boy was seven years older than I with a gentle Superman wave of hair at his forehead and broad shoulders that defied the reedy build of our South Indian heritage. The son of a family friend, he often visited us in our northeast Indiana town, a few miles east of the Dan Quayle museum. Affable with dinner guests and handy with sports scores, he was adored by my parents. And I realized quickly, despite my parents' denials, that they wanted me to marry him.

headline.main: Mom, Dad, Let Me Find My Own Husband
headline.print_headline: MODERN LOVE; Mom, Dad, Let Me Find My Own Husband

abstract: Recalling the wait for a favorite dish and a life away from the war.
snippet: Recalling the wait for a favorite dish and a life away from the war.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, while my parents traveled to the United States to assess a possible life there, they rented a chalet in the Lebanese coastal town Jounieh and left us in the care of my maternal grandmother. It was a thrilling summer for me. More than any of my siblings, I was tired of the war in Lebanon, which had been going strong for almost a decade. I was particularly fed up with living in constant fear — from the shellings, the sniper attacks, the bombings, the checkpoints, the kidnappings and the threats directed at my Palestinian-born parents, who met and married in Beirut. I spent much of my time daydreaming about a new, perfect and utterly ‘‘normal’’ life in America.
